html: 6.7.19  10:00 pm   I was just thinking about your 12-tet experiment, and I just realized, how would people with relative pitch deal with this? If they just hopped around "perfect" intervals they would slowly get out of tune with the original key. So do you almost have to somehow temper your notes as you sing / play them? Or do people just do that automatically? Sorry if my question makes no sense.

6.7.19  5:43 pm   i'm 18 and i'm going to college and i have to decide on a career, but i am conflicted. i tried to know myself, what i'm capable of, what i wanna do. i wanted to make music since i was 15 but i just started to learn to play the keyboard. i've narrowed down to 2 career paths, one being music (i don't know how to make it yet), and programming. i really love music but i'm not sure on programming. and i'm not even sure if i wanna be a programmer but i can't think of anything else that's suitable for me. it's been fine till now but right now it's like "hey man, you gotta choose what you wanna do until you die or something" and it's really hard to settle on one thing, or being sure that it's the thing i want to do for a long long time. any advice?

6.6.19  11:31 pm   i am dealing with muddy mixes right now and it is bothering me.  like the whole bottom end feels like it has a heaviness.  i don't feel air in-between the instruments.  even in your earlier stuff where you espouse mix trouble i still hear the distinctness and space. one part of me knows it is an arrangement problem.  and part of me also feels like it is a problem of using electric bass and hardware instruments. and then part of it feels like my actual mixing itself or lackthereof.  part may be vocals, cheap mic, or recording too much room noise.  urgh.  it probably isnt even that horrible for how bad the problem feels.  how would you start to troubleshoot?  arrangement first?
